user_request: A poem where the speaker hears America singing, each worker their own song.

revision_history.draft:
America sings—steel bones groan, a factory’s throat  
coughing sparks into the dark. A welder’s hymn,  
molten and jagged, slices the anthem’s throat.  
A janitor’s song, a scrub brush’s  
whisper—  
America sings—  
a hymn of bleach and knees,  
scraping the anthem’s floor clean.  
America sings—  
a truck’s tire hums a hymn,  
but the driver’s  
lungs are reed pipes,  
blowing  
dissonant  
notes through the  
anthem’s  
static.  
A nurse’s song, a stethoscope’s  
tick,  
America sings—  
but the rhythm  
is a heartbeat  
drowning  
in the  
anthem’s  
static.  
The anthem’s a machine  
with a thousand  
voices  
grinding  
in its  
gears—  
America sings,  
but the song  
is a  
fracture,  
a  
dissonant  
chord,  
unresolved.
revision_history.critique:
**What’s alive:**  
The mechanical metaphors (“steel bones,” “lungs as reed pipes”) effectively contrast industrial and organic sounds, creating tension between

final_poem:
America sings—steel bones groan, a factory’s throat  
coughs sparks into the dark. A welder’s hymn,  
molten and jagged, splits the anthem’s spine.  
A janitor’s song, a scrub brush’s  
whisper—  
America sings—  
a hymn of bleach and knees,  
scraping the anthem’s floor clean.  
America sings—  
a truck’s tire hums a hym,  
but the driver’s  
lungs are reed pipes,  
blowing  
dissonant  
notes through the  
anthem’s  
static.  
A nurse’s song, a stethoscope’s  
tick,  
America sings—  
yet the rhythm  
is a heartbeat  
drowning  
in the  
anthem’s  
static.  
The anthem’s a machine  
with a thousand  
voices  
grinding  
in its  
gears—  
America sings,  
but the song  
is a  
fracture,  
a  
dissonant  
chord,  
unresolved.
